Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The role of resource mutualisms in plant adaptation to abiotic environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants can overcome environmental stress by dispersing to less stressful habitats, adapting to the stress, or associating with other organisms, such as microbes, that help reduce the stress. Although the third strategy of coping with stress has received very little attention, there is increasing evidence that it is both common and effective. Soil bacteria called rhizobia act like natural fertilizer by converting nitrogen in the atmosphere into a form that at least some plants can use. In return, those plants provide energy to the rhizobia. The goal of this study is to determine whether rhizobia help plants survive under extreme water stress. This research is important because increasing drought stress is predicted for much of the world under global climate change and rhizobia are one of the most likely ways that plants may overcome that stress. This has practical implications. For example, understanding the plant-rhizobium partnership may help reduce application of synthetic fertilizers or unnecessary use of water in agriculture systems. Results will be shared broadly through presentations at national and regional meetings as well as in high school classrooms and in newsletters for naturalists and land managers. The researchers will also create and publish inquiry-based activities for high school students that are aligned with the Advanced Placement (AP) biology Curriculum.

Specifically, this research will investigate how resource mutualists influence plant adaptation to soil moisture in the field. Using the legume-rhizobia mutualism as a model system, investigators aim to expand understanding of the mechanisms contributing to local adaptation, how species interactions influence local adaptation, and the traits underlying adaptation. Three specific questions will be addressed: (1) Are plants locally adapted to soil moisture conditions? (2) Do resource mutualists contribute to plant adaptation to soil moisture? And, (3) what plant traits drive adaptation to wet vs. dry environments? These questions will be tackled with an integrated set of reciprocal transplant experiments across multiple sites differing in soil moisture, with manipulative greenhouse experiments, and with molecular analyses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interactions between microbes and plants are ubiquitous in nature and can be beneficial to plants. For example, plants in the legume family engage in mutualistic (mutually beneficial) interactions with arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) and nitrogen-fixing bacteria (rhizobia). In these classic examples of mutualism, plants trade carbon fixed through photosynthesis for phosphorus scavenged by AMF or nitrogen fixed by rhizobia. These mutualisms not only help plants obtain nutrients, however, they can also help plants withstand other challenges such as drought stress or soil acidification. In some cases, closely associated microbes may even facilitate plant adaptation to stressful environments. Using an annual legume, Amphicarpaea bracteata, and nitrogen-fixing bacteria, Bradyrhizobium sp., as a model system, we investigated how rhizobia influence plant fitness (survival and seed production) responses to drought stress and whether interactions with rhizobia contribute to adaptation to drought.

First, we demonstrated that soil moisture is an important selective agent driving plant adaptation and showed that rhizobia influence patterns of plant adaption to soil moisture. These results suggest that rhizobia play a key role in plant adaptation to drought and that plant traits facilitating interactions with particular microorganisms may be key adaptations. Given the intimate relationship between plants and symbiotic microbes, such as mycorrhizae, endophytes and rhizobia, such patterns may be prevalent in nature. Second, we found that the plant and rhizobium populations we studied were tightly coevolved and that rhizobia performance was strongly affected by the match between rhizobium origin and plant origin. Specifically, rhizobia collected from wet environments performed best on plants that also were collected from wet environments, and rhizobia collected from dry environments performed best on plants that were collected from dry environments. These data suggest that plants that have evolved in wet vs. dry sites differ in traits that differentially benefit rhizobium genotypes isolated from wet versus dry sites.

Our findings provide new evidence that microorganisms may be even more beneficial to plants than previously recognized. Even in well-studied interactions like the legume-rhizobium mutualism, new benefits were observed; however, these benefits differed across rhizobium populations collected from different locations and often depended on the match between the plant population, the rhizobium population, and the abiotic environment. Given the potential for microbes to rapidly adapt to changing environmental conditions, plant traits facilitating interactions with particularly beneficial microbes may be powerful and extremely flexible adaptations.
